post_text: We need our parent partner’s help! When asked about the ability to drive or car pool, 50% of our parents indicated they could provide transportation for their students. As drivers begin running routes to determine times and schedules, we are finding that far more parents are utilizing bus transport than originally indicated. We have added three additional buses, but our buses are at, or very near normal capacity. This is not acceptable for our students or drivers. Please remember that during these difficult times the Hanover family has pulled together and supported our schools. If possible, PLEASE consider providing transportation, particularly at the Middle School and High School levels. Together, we can keep everyone SAFE, but alone, it is an impossible task.

I remain committed to returning in-person and on time for the beginning of the 2020-2021 school year.

My decision is based on the following known factors:

1. I am confident we can start the school year safely. How long in-person classes remain open is dependent upon community compliance with safe practices.

2. Starting the school year on time and in-person will allow us to build relationships with kids that will serve to help recover the learning losses from the end of the 2019-2020 school year. Further, it will support virtual learning efforts should it become necessary. Those relationships are critical to future learning.

A copy of our final updates to the Hanover Community School Corporation Re-Entry Plan can be found in the “Announcements” section of our website at www.hanover.k12.in.us

Mary Tracy-MacAulay
Superintendent
Hanover Community Schools

Dear Hanover Staff and Families,

I wanted to take this opportunity to express my sincerest gratitude to ALL of you, staff and families alike, during Staff Appreciation Week 2020 because it has truly required all of us to work together, while being apart.

This is a time in which we have all experienced a myriad of emotions: confusion, sadness, loneliness, anger, wonder, happiness and gratitude, to name just a few. However, through it all, I remain humbled by the heart and commitment of the entire staff and Hanover community.

Collectively, we have pulled together on behalf of our children. There is nothing more honorable, humbling, or fulfilling than rising to meet this challenge time and time again. Take a moment today to celebrate that which is most important...the human spirit and being there for one another.

I am grateful for the work ALL of you have done for our kids and I am grateful that you are MY village.

Mary MacAulay

post_text: There were many friendly faces this afternoon at Jane Ball Elementary School for breakfast and lunch food distribution. Food was brought to the cars as they pulled up and lined up around Jane Ball. In just a half hour more than 250 dinners were distributed. Director of Student Nutrition Services Michelle Philipp was on hand to keep track of the numbers. All in all 1000 meals were distributed today--500 breakfasts and 500 lunches. On hand to help Michelle were her staff Kathy Bolger, Kelli Ribicki and RaeLynn Janes. Also on hand were Mike O'Donnell, Director of School Safety and Security, and Jane Ball Principal Ryan Eckart. Michelle's other staff that have helped include Amy Einesee, Linda Marks and Raquel Gonsiorowski.

post_text: Earlier today, a student at Jane Ball Elementary School brought an empty handgun magazine to school and showed it to other students at recess. The student who had seen the magazine immediately told an adult who then asked the student and was shown the item. The adult then took the item and turned it over to the school resource officers working in the building. The student was brought to the main office by the SRO. The magazine was empty so the SRO and Principal then searched the rest of the student's belongings and did not locate anything else. Parents of the student who brought the magazine to school were contacted, a meeting was held and consequences were given. The student that reported the incident was thanked by Mr. Eckart, CLPD Chief Fisher, Hanover School Safety Director O'Donnell and SRO Corbin. No students were ever in danger and the matter was dealt with immediately. At Hanover we stress that if you See Something, Say Something and in this case everyone worked together on the matter.

post_text: On Thursday Dec. 5, the students in Tracy Sheehy's Intro to Culinary Class at Hanover Central High School welcomed Harry Hanford from Hanford Packing and Larry Willey from Indiana Farm Bureau. Every year for the last 30 plus years Mr. Hanford has come to Hanover's foods classes to talk to the students about his career as a butcher, and to cut up a half of a pig that is donated by Larry Willey and Indiana Farm Bureau. The students learn where different cuts of meat come from, including bacon from the belly to the baby back ribs and how cutting a piece different can make it into a different cut of meat. The pig that is cut is taken back to Hanfords where he finishes the processing of the pig, and it is then returned to Hanover for the Culinary and Foods classes to use in the food labs.

Earlier this evening, a student made a statement on Snapchat that appeared to be a threat against Hanover Central Middle School. It was immediately brought to the school’s attention by concerned parents. It was investigated by the police and found to be a false alarm. There is no threat to the students, and school will be in session on Monday, November 18, 2019. It is through the quick response and efforts of parents, students, and staff that concerns such as these can be investigated and the responsible parties determined. Once again, there is no threat and school will be in session.

Mary Tracy-MacAulay
Superintendent

We need and want your input regarding the facilities and our growing enrollment at Hanover.

We are able to engage with parents, community partners, and staff using an interactive online tool called 'Thought Exchange'. A thought exchange allows you to post your ideas anonymously, as well as rate the ideas of others.

The question we are asking is, "As one of the fastest growing school districts in Indiana we need to plan to meet this challenge. As we explore ways to improve facilities and provide more opportunities for our students what are the most important ideas we need to consider?"

Below is the link for the Thought Exchange. It will remain open until Wednesday, October 23rd. Please share your thoughts and comment on the thoughts of others.

https://my.thoughtexchange.com/#520410664

Thank you,

Mary Tracy-MacAulay, Ed.S.
Superintendent
Hanover Community Schools
mtracy@hanover.k12.in.us
(219) 374-3500

The first Community Conversation was held Tuesday night at Hanover Central High School. Superintendent Mary Tracy-MacAulay highlighted the District's continued high achievement pattern. E-Learning plans, the graduation pathways and updates on the high school were also discussed.

“A blended learning environment is important and enhances instruction, but it is not intended to take the place of the teacher. That relationship is pivotal to learning," Macaulay said. Assistant School Superintendent, Deborah Snedden, talked about the Graduation Pathways and the changes that are happening to prepare students for life beyond high school to ensure their continued success. High School Principal, Tami Kepshire, focused on the great things happening at Hanover. “I want the students to have fun while learning. This is an opportunity to showcase our students,” Kepshire said.

post_text: At tonight's Hanover Community School Corporation Board of Trustee's meeting, Amanda Rode, Hanover’s Athletic Sports Trainer, was the recipient of the Safe Sport School Award from the National Association of Athletic Trainers. Rode thanked the Great Lakes Athletic Trainers Association for supplying a grant for the applications fee and also thanked the Trainers Association for the award. This is Rode’s fourth year as athletic trainer. Represented by Community Hospital, Rode has to make sure the school is compliant in a variety of factors. “We have to create a positive health care team and we have to communicate with the medical staff,” Rode said. “We provide pre-participation physicals every year and the student athletes have to have physicals before their very first practice.” Rode received a certificate and a banner that will be placed at the field house. “I want to thank everyone that has helped us get this award,” Rode said. Congratulations Amanda Rode!

Getting out into the community, Hanover bus drivers participated in Touch a Truck event
The Hanover School District was well represented at the Touch a Truck event at American Legion Post 261 in Cedar Lake. Buses 18, 16 and 42 were on hand to show a variety of transportation for students, special needs and extracurriculars. Rain did not dampen the spirits of the visitors who checked out the event. About 80 families and children came through and they learned about the buses. Parents were happy to have their younger children checking out the buses. And yes, the horns did work! On hand to help with the event were Shelly Ward, Mike Bond and Gayle Santefort. Children were given candy and coloring sheets and the parents were taught about the safety of the school bus and laws and rules about stop arm violations. “The event encouraged people who are stay at home moms or relatives to think about bus driving or becoming an aide on the bus or in the schools,” Ms. Ward said. Despite the rainy weather it was a win for the schools and the community!

Children were given candy and coloring sheets and the parents were taught about the safety of the school bus and laws and rules about stop arm violations. “The event encouraged people who are stay at home moms or relatives to think about bus driving or becoming an aide on the bus or in the schools,” Ms. Ward said. Despite the rainy weather it was a win for the schools and the community!
